definition: to delegate power/to decentralize
to put/to place/to release/to free/to let go/to let out/to set off (fireworks)
surname Quan
authority/power/right/(literary) to weigh/expedient/temporary

sentences.english: EB members readily agreed that more authority should be delegated to country offices.
sentences.chinese: 执委们爽快同意应向国家办事处进一步放权。

sentences.english: Increased delegation of authority goes together with a demand for increased transparency and accountability.
sentences.chinese: 在进一步放权的同时，需要提高透明度和增强问责制。

sentences.english: The government has also streamlined its administration and delegated authority, and innovated and improved government approval services.
sentences.chinese: 不断推进简政放权，创新优化行政审批服务方式。

sentences.english: China started its reforms with the devolution of central power, especially regional decentralization.
sentences.chinese: 中国的经济改革始于放权，尤其是对地区的放权。

sentences.english: China started its reforms with the devolution of central power, especially regional decentralization.
sentences.chinese: 中国的经济改革始于放权，尤其是对地区的放权。

definition: separation of powers
position/authority/responsibility
ability to make one's own decisions
property ownership or right/financial power/financial control
to attend to everything personally
lit. to go beyond the sacrificial altar and take over the kitchen (idiom); fig. to exceed one's place and meddle in other people's affairs/to take matters into one's own hands
power/authority
to decide and act alone (idiom); to take arbitrary action/a law unto oneself
to take complete charge (idiom)
to decide alone without consultation/arbitrary/dictatorial
power/authority
to check and balance (power)/checks and balances
to act arbitrarily/to make decisions without consulting others
expert at appointing people according to their abilities (idiom)/to put the right people in the right places
(lit.) to hold sb by the elbow/(fig.) to hold back/to impede/to handicap
to stand aside and do nothing (idiom)/to take no part in
